Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2015 (PRFB)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2015, Broadening Participation. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow and a plan to broaden participation of groups under-represented in science. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Derek Caetano-Anollés is "Genetic framework for mouse facial structure under selective pressures." The host institution for this fellowship is the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology in Plön, Germany, and the sponsoring scientist is Diethard Tautz. This fellowship is funded jointly with the Office of International Science and Engineering. Forming international collaborations is not only beneficial to the young scientist who conducts research at the foreign location but is also in the U.S. national interest because that experience in a world-class research organization exposes the next generation of science leaders to the best the host country has to offer in terms of state-of-the-art research and the promises of continuing collaborations that will continue to strengthen U.S. science in the future

The fellowship research is identifying genes that are responsible for controlling skull shape and facial structure of mice during their development, and how those features are impacted by evolutionary and selection pressures. It seeks to validate the functions of these genes, laying the groundwork for future work that will not only lead to a better understanding of mouse developmental genetics in regards to face structure but develop a finely-tuned set of software and techniques that can then be used to look at various anatomical systems in other organism models as well. This line of research has very exciting prospects for its potential to predict facial morphology from genetic information. The technology being developed is being used to gain the means and knowledge to better understand the fundamental evolutionary forces that shape cranial change in response to environmental and food adaptations.

Training goals include gaining expertise in genetics, husbandry and genomics in mice, and in the CRISPR/Cas genome editing system and its transformative applications to genome biology. Educational outreach to undergraduates and graduate students is through mentoring and serving as a role model and conducted at the Institute for Evolutionary Biology and the University of Kiel.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Exploring and identifying the genetic components that direct the structure of organisms has remained a major focus of developmental and evolutionary biology. Morphology can evolve very rapidly in populations, which can lead to novel adaptations in response to environmental changes. Here, we focus on a set of candidate genes responsible for developing the morphological features of the skull and mandible of the mouse (Mus musculus), while comparing these morphological effects to those found in rat (Rattus norvegicus). Using RNA-seq at different time points in development, we confirm that the strongest contrasts exist between early and late developmental time points, with a small subset of genes in the head demonstrating an elevated number of haplotype effects. The Sh3pxd2b gene leads to stunted cranial growth when knocked-out, and shows the most mutational differences in wild-type individuals, not only in the number of haplotypes but also in the number of differences between each haplotype.

In 2014, a number of genes were identified by Pallares et al. (Molecular Ecology, 2014), as being significantly involved in controlling and regulating craniofacial development in rodents. These genes were Cldn18, Foxl2, Gab1, Mn1, Rab3c, Sh3pxd2b, and Tbx15. Of these candidates, Sh3pxd2b was known to results in a shrunken face in mice who have this gene knocked out. During the course of this project, it was found that RNA expression of Sh3pxd2b is particularly active during early embryonic development in the head. This pattern was comparable to expression for Gab1. Perhaps unsurprisingly, Mn1 (shown to cause cleft palates in individuals with knocked-out genes) expressed RNA more highly in the head than in the body during development. Other candidate genes showed varying levels of expression between head and body over the course of embryonic development, demonstrating that there is no simple pattern that explains the behavior of all these candidate genes, which are most likely acting in concert with many other biological systems.

The RNA transcripts for each of the candidate genes were sequenced, looking variations at the single-nucleotide level that would produce a tapestry of haplotypes during early development—while most candidates had relatively homogenous expression of their genes, Mn1 and Sh3pxd2b were interestingly found to possess the most variation at the single-nucleotide level. It is perhaps as a result of this that both of these genes, when knocked out of experimental mice, produce the most striking phenotypes.
